reviews.review_msg: She was a friendly and understanding professor, but the rubric criteria she handed out for each assignment/ worksheet were sometimes unclear. Even so, if you're interested in learning about Technologies of Health and Expectations, you should be warned that she can be a bit strict when grading your assignments plus towards the final paper.

Stacy is generally a nice person. She tends to ramble on a lot during lectures making them hard to follow especially since she does not provide any powerpoints. If you prefer more holistic teaching styles, she may be for you. I found her difficult to please, especially for the final assignments. I would not recommend this course unless you need it.
Tough course, short time limits but amazing professor.

Seminars wasted valuable time, weekly assignments/readings were for in-class discussions that rarely occurred. Assignments released late, students expected to complete them less than 24h before due date & no extensions. Group project left until last 3 weeks of classes. Some assignments still haven't been graded when submitted over a month ago.

Good prof with a clear passion for the course material. Amazing at lifting students up and considering all things discussed in class. Be kind and participate! Sometimes disorganized and late with marking but is open about this and does her best to compensate students. Lectures are casual and inviting. Prof is kind and easy to approach.

the class I took was very lecture and discussion heavy, but like I said, she repeated concepts over and over in order to hammer things into our heads.  Basically spoon fed us what she's looking for in the papers, so don't complain that there's too many. Very motherly in terms of how approachable she is. Also replied to emails very quickly.
The course was interesting but assignment instructions were not very clear.

This was my first Anthropology course and I am blown away . Material are very interesting, she is very passionate but not an easy grader. The course structure is very loose and she is sometimes unorganized but in the same way she treats her students as human beings you can get extensions and can ask her anything. Loved the course.

Lazy, lazy prof. Her online course is never updated and is a mess, does not take any suggestions. More reading than 4th year classes. By far the worst online experience I have ever had at SFU. Says to buy textbook, but all info is in study guide. Does not care about students one bit.
Interesting class. Fair marking. Passionate prof.

Stacy is very passionate about anthropology, which makes her class more interesting. With that being said, her teaching method is different from the usual memorize and regurgitated for exams. She looks for more in depth understanding of material. A lot of work for a 100 class but if interested in the topic interesting! She's also a bit disorganized

Stacy is one of the best professors I have ever had. She genuinely wants her students to grapple with difficult questions and will take your concerns seriously. Plus, she has a great sense of humor, is approachable, and brilliant. If you are interested and enthusiastic about contemporary concerns in anthropology, take Stacy's class.

An insightful instructor who will reward those who do the reading and really make an effort with  written assignments. Always available for a good discussion in office hours and to clarify assignments. Makes an effort to build rapport with students. Not easy material, but does repeatedly emphasize the big themes and important criteria.

One of the most unstructured, disorganized and ditzy instructors ive ever had. Her assignments are confusing, and she'll wait until a week before an essays due to tell u what its about. She's late, and goes over time and doesnt give breaks. She plays harsh favs. God have mercy on your grade if ur not one of them.DONT TAKE HER CLASS

Key: there are no right answers, only good explanations. She is very helpful IF you are clear in your questions. Most people who didn't like the course just don't like the vague-ness of anthropology, NOT Dr.Pigg's fault. I found the subject matter to be interesting but challenging. Very discussion-based= tutorials are important for understanding!

I would recommend this course for those who are not interested in anthropology. She talks a lot in lecture/tutorial and you can get confused about what to write down/not to write down. She goes over the time of classes all the time too. Not really an engaging class

my first time taking anthropology..Stacey is a good prof but sometimes sidetracks her lectures...listening about her fieldwork is good but sometimes she leaves the juicy part of the lecture for the last 10 mins and cramms everything in....
prof. pigg was awesome! her lectures were a little bit boring but the readings were good for the most part. the tutorials really make this class try to get a good tutorial leader. its a pretty easy A

Stacy Pigg is honestly the worst prof I've ever had. I sat in class while she rambled off-topic about her irrelevant life, when there were interesting topics she did not choose to explore. If you ever see a class taught by Pigg, don't take it, this is hands down the worst class I've ever taken.

Stacy is a really great prof, but you should go into this class with an actual interest in anthro. Her lectures are a little scattered, but she keeps you involved. I did well in her class and only read the ethnographic book, and not the text book. Recommend her as a prof to an anthro student.
naive and disorganized, poor time management, vague and off topic, and hard marker
This teacher is completely disorganized. She plays favourites. She is a hard marker. The comments she gives on assignments are the complete opposites of what her instructions say.

She is passionate about anthropology, but her lectures were hard to endure because she didn't have any objective thoughts about what she was teaching. She would always say 'there are no clear answers'. This post-modern way of teaching was very discouraging and unhelpful

One of the most disorganized teachers I've ever seen. Her notes are irrelevant to what appears in exams, and she spends way too much time talking about her own fieldwork. When it comes to  finals/midterms, the course is so vague have no idea what to study.

She is very disorganized, and spends most of the lecture talking about her own life and research, which is interesting enough, but come time for the final you will be at a loss of what to study. I have notes on probably half the things she put on the review sheet, I have no idea where the other terms are coming from.

I loved her class, and loved working with her. She was really knowledgable and passionate. Somewhat disorganized and VERY busy, but full of ideas, personable, and great at facilitating discussions. Would take a class with her again.

She is very passionate about the material and knows what she is talking about! It is absolutely mandatory to attend lectures and read the texts....if the time is put in you will see the grades! I am certain anyone posting negative feedback simply didn't stay on top of the material. She favours students who actually DO the work!!

She was the course supervisor and was absolutely useless; I don't know what they pay her for. She wasn't even around for the final.  TA was anal.  The course/concepts are easy to understand but the expectations for the papers are unreasonable.

She was late every class, we never got a break for the two hour lecture -never she kept us over every time sometimes for 20 extra minutes she said we as a class didnt understand the assignments so she had to grade them differently-really she didnt noe what she assigned marking was hard so hard she nices tho but i would have her again

Stacy Leigh is very passionate and knowledgeable. She encourages class room discussions so long as students take the time to read all the material assigned (that includes book readings, journal articles, website info, etc). There is alot of work, and its not an easy grade, but shes very outgoing, cracks jokes, and is sincerely kind to students.
Absolutely fantastic! She is a personable person and gives the same curtsies to you. Work hard and you'll do fine. :)

If you like profs that say 'like' every 20seconds, teach you more about their own family that the class material and leave you wondering how anything they have tried to teach you could be examable.. then this prof is for you!

In the beginning, students are not sure what she wants as she is not clear. However she teaches in a manner that makes you think and by the end of the class you will "get it."  IT takes awhild to understand her style but when you do, its a lot of fun.

It was always unclear what we were actually supposed to be learning in Stacy's class. The concepts are not that difficult, but the way they are presented leaves you constantly wondering if you're getting the point. Every grade was a total surprise. A+ for knowledge/enthusiasm, C- for clarity.

Very cheery, enthusiastic prof. Material really makes you look hard at your own cultural background. Many good videos shown in class, but lots of readings and abstract concepts. She seems to be a bit nervous around large groups of students in her lectures however, but is very nice. Her doctoral work is very interesting.
BORING
No Comments
really great for someone who wants to get into anthropology. Lot's of reading though, and really abstract.
No Comments

Every time Stacy says something like "I'm not going to teach you facts. I want to teach you how to ask questions." I have this overwhelming urge to put up my hand and say "What's on the midterm?" Lectures are interesting but vague and I'm always unsure about where they're actually going. I can say she's very passionate about what she does...
No Comments

I've had 3 classes with Stacy. She can come across as a ditz, but she is so smart, and incredibly helpful (if you get past the jargon). She is an over-achiever & expects you to be. Quite heavy with readings, but I highly recommend her if you are interested in the topic (& are willing to read lots).

Stacy is a very knowledgeable professor.  She believes that reading will help students to understand the "local perspectives" in a culture.  But, sometimes there are too much reading to get that that one theme she is trying to point out. look go

Stacy is a very passionate academic, but she assigns way too much reading which should have been considered "recommended" instead of "manditory".She is really disorganized.I really liked the classroom environment and the course materia
i was excited about this class but i cant honestly it was wirth the time

aaaaaaaaaahhhhhh.i agree with all of the other comments. stacey should stick with grad classes. she demonstrates a high level of interest in her topic but come on we are undergrads, be resonable, we arent pashionate about anything but graduating.
smart, helpful, questions but doesn't shoot you down, but phases in and out

Very passionate and well-informed professor on her research subject, but in-class she is unprepared to take on her own course load.  Her level of intellectual thought would be better suited for grad students, not undergrads...also a space monkey...
